NYU | Drama Lit | Undergraduate Program                                                                                             The Major and Minor in Dramatic Literature at NYU   The standard Dramatic Literature major consists of ten courses within the department, including V30.0110 and V30.0111; one course in dramatic literature before 1800; a minimum of two (maximum of seven) Dramatic Literature electives; and no more than five courses in cinema studies and practical theatre. Transfer students must complete at least five of the 10 courses at the College. Note: C- is the lowest grade that may be counted toward the major provided that the overall average in dramatic literature courses, including the C- course, is C or above.   The standard Dramatic Literature minor consists of any four V30 courses offered by the department. Transfer students must complete at least two of the four courses at the College. Note: C- is the lowest grade that may be counted toward the minor provided that the overall average in dramatic literature courses, including the C- course, is C or above. Courses fulfilling distribution requirements:   Please note that the titles of certain courses vary from semester to semester. You should go by the number rather than the title in determining the requirement fulfilled by such courses. Njus: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Drama Drama News & Events Box Office About The Program How To Apply Faculty Administration Student Center Production Resource Office Production Archive High School Programs Summer in Drama Alumni FAQ  home > Drama          Drama   Jesse Njus Associate Teacher Phone: 212-992-8431 Email: jnjus@nyu.edu Office: 726 Broadway, Rm 246 Office Hours: By Appointment  Courses Medieval Theatre Religion and Theatre Introduction to Theatre Studies Education Ph.D. Northwestern University (2010) B.A. University of Wisconsin-Madison (2002) Biography A medievalist whose subspecialties are Classical, early modern, and global medieval drama, Jesse received her Ph.D. from Northwestern University's Interdisciplinary Program in Theatre and Drama. Prior to arriving at NYU, she was an ACLS New Faculty Fellow at the University of California-Santa Barbara with a joint appointment in the Departments of English and Theater/Dance. Her current book project, The People’s Passion: Staging the Vernacular Passion Plays of Medieval Europe , will be the first comprehensive comparative study of the vernacular Passion plays, one of the most important elements of medieval theatre. Jesse is also beginning work on her second project, Global Moralities: Staging Morality Plays throughout the Medieval World . Global Moralities will break new ground by moving beyond the confines of Western European Christianity to analyze medieval morality plays from a global perspective. Jesse's award-winning article, “The Politics of Mysticism: Elisabeth of Spalbeek in Context,” appeared in the refereed journal Church History and is the first full historical study of Elisabeth, a mid-thirteenth-century female performer of Christ’s passion. Jesse has also published in Theatre Journal (on medieval acting) and in Fifteenth-Century Studies (on the importance of Englishwoman Margery Kempe to the study of theatrical spectatorship). Jesse's essay comparing the staging techniques of medieval pageants depicting the Last Supper will be included in the collection Culinary Theatres edited by Dorothy Chansky and Ann White.
